item.title: A Baldurâ€™s Gate TV Show Is Happening In The Worst Way Possible
item.content:encoded:
Three days ago, I was talking about how sometimes good things happen, like HBOâ€™s bunk-ass live-action The Last of Us series looking likely to end in three seasons rather than four. Well, the monkeyâ€™s paw didnâ€™t just curl, it rolled in upon itself with an intensity great enough to open a portal to a much, much worse dimension. Craig Mazin, whio serves as showrunner on the post-apocalyptic adaptation, isnâ€™t done at HBO; heâ€™s now apparently working on a Baldurâ€™s Gate series that will continue the story of Larian Studiosâ€™ RPG. Just shoot me, HBO.

Deadline reports that Mazin is working alongside Hasbro to create a continuation of the Baldurâ€™s Gate 3 story that will include both new characters and some returning ones from the game. You know, the ones whose fates you could have greatly influenced with your decisions in ways too drastic for the writers to have any wiggle room in making sweeping choices for them? I already donâ€™t trust Mazin with characters when heâ€™s following the source materialâ€™s script, much less continuing their stories beyond the credits. According to Deadlineâ€˜s story, Mazin has full creative control. Call me Gale Dekarios of Waterdeep the way I could explode right now.

â€œAfter putting nearly 1000 hours into the incredible world of Baldurâ€™s Gate 3, it is a dream come true to be able to continue the story that Larian and Wizards of The Coast created,â€ Mazin said in a statement to Deadline. â€œI am a devoted fan of D&D and the brilliant way that Swen Vincke and his gifted team adapted it. I canâ€™t wait to help bring Baldurâ€™s Gate and all of its incredible characters to life with as much respect and love as we can, and Iâ€™m deeply grateful to Gabe Marano and his team at Hasbro for entrusting me with this incredibly important property.â€

Thanks, I hate it. And Iâ€™ll inevitably be putting my boxing gloves on once more to enter the ring when it comes out like I did for The Last of Us.

item.title: Overwatchâ€™s New Jetpack-Using Cat Hero Is An Agent Of Pure Chaos
item.content:encoded:
I do not fear many things in Overwatch, but I am beginning to fear Jetpack Cat. The flying feline hero is exactly what she sounds like, a cat that has endless flight and zooms around the map healing allies and pestering foes. However, she also has the ability to tether her teammates to her craft and fly them around the battlefield. The strategies and combos players have already found in just a brief early access period are incredibly chaotic.

I played a little bit of Jetpack Cat myself when I tried my hand at all five of Overwatchâ€™s new heroes last month, and while I donâ€™t think she will be joining my support hero rotation anytime soon, Iâ€™m already anticipating the ridiculous plays teams will pull off with her if theyâ€™re coordinating. The catâ€™s tether requires a teammate to opt in, meaning you donâ€™t have to worry about any Lifeweaver-style trolling or accidentally latching onto her and being taken for a ride. 

Once youâ€™re tethered, Jetpack Cat can fly you anywhere, as long as you donâ€™t get shot down by the enemy team. But her tether isnâ€™t limited to just teammates, it can also pick up things like Asheâ€™s Omnic ultimate B.O.B. as he fires down on the unsuspecting foes below, or D.Vaâ€™s mech suit after sheâ€™s set it to self destruct. This way you have a brief window to fix a bad play or placement. Meanwhile, Jetpack Catâ€™s ultimate lets her tether onto an enemy and drag them off the map or out of a fortified area, so youâ€™re not just restricted to picking up friendlies. Thereâ€™s a lot of potential and not a ton of limitations. Some early players have used dueling Jetpack Cats to pit two of their respective teammates against each other in an airborne battle.
